title: 104_hr4110
content: The "Children Health Insurance Act of 1996" is cited as the short title. It amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a section on Health Insurance Availability for Children, which imposes an excise tax for failure to provide access to coverage. A tax is imposed on group health plans and insurers for failing to meet coverage requirements. The tax amount is 25 percent of premiums received for the plan year. Self-insured plans treat the cost of coverage as premiums. Insurers offering individual health insurance are also subject to the tax. The tax imposed on group health plans and insurers for failing to meet coverage requirements is 25 percent of premiums received for the plan year. Self-insured plans treat the cost of coverage as premiums. The tax does not apply if the failure was not discovered despite reasonable diligence. The tax imposed on group health plans and insurers for failing to meet coverage requirements is 25 percent of premiums received for the plan year. No tax is imposed if the failure was not discovered despite reasonable diligence. The tax may be waived if the failure was due to reasonable cause and not willful neglect. The tax imposed on group health plans and insurers for failing to meet coverage requirements can be waived if the failure was due to reasonable cause and not willful neglect. This tax does not apply to governmental plans or church plans. The responsible parties for the tax are the plan for group health plans and the insurer for health insurance coverage. "SEC. 9902. REQUIREMENT OF ACCESS TO COVERAGE." Group health plans must offer qualifying coverage for qualifying young dependents of participants or beneficiaries. The offer must be made when a person first becomes a qualifying young dependent and annually thereafter. Insurers in the individual market must offer qualifying coverage for individuals under 21 years old who are US citizens or nationals. Qualifying coverage includes health care benefits without limitations based on pre-existing conditions. Qualifying coverage under this section includes Medicare benefits and well child care benefits, with no pre-existing condition limitations or waiting periods. Payment for newborn and well-baby care, well-child care, routine office visits, immunizations, laboratory tests, and preventive dental care is provided without deductibles, coinsurance, or copayments. Well-child care, including routine office visits, immunizations, laboratory tests, and preventive dental care, is covered without deductibles, coinsurance, or copayments. The Secretary, in consultation with the American Academy of Pediatrics, establishes a periodicity schedule for these services. Managed care is permitted as long as there is reasonable access to benefits. A qualifying young dependent is defined as an individual under a certain age. The term 'qualifying young dependent' refers to an individual under 21 years of age, residing in the United States, who is a citizen or national (or alien permanently residing in the US under color of law), and a dependent as defined in section 152. There are no limitations on the providers through whom benefits can be accessed as long as there is reasonable access. "SEC. 9903. DEFINITIONS." - This section provides definitions for terms used in the document. "In this chapter, the term 'group health plan' is defined as per section 5000(b)(1), excluding plans with medical benefits limited to coverage in paragraph (2)(B). 'Health insurance coverage' refers to benefits for medical care under various policies or contracts, excluding coverage for accident or credit-only policies." The curr_chunk discusses exceptions to the term "health insurance coverage," including coverage for accident, vision, disability income, long-term care, dental care, Medicare supplemental insurance, liability insurance supplements, and general liability insurance. The curr_chunk lists various types of insurance coverage that are exceptions to the term "health insurance coverage," including liability insurance, workers' compensation, automobile medical-payment insurance, coverage for specified diseases, hospital indemnity insurance, short-term limited duration insurance, and other comparable coverage specified in regulations. The curr_chunk defines a health maintenance organization as a federally qualified organization, one recognized under State law, or a similar organization regulated for solvency under State law. The curr_chunk further elaborates on the definition of an insurer in the context of health insurance coverage in the individual market, specifying that it includes insurance companies, services, organizations, and health maintenance organizations licensed to operate in a State and subject to state insurance regulations. The curr_chunk defines the individual market for health insurance coverage and incorporates certain definitions related to beneficiaries and participants. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The curr_chunk introduces a requirement for health insurance coverage for children effective January 1, 1998, regardless of plan year start date. It also establishes a refundable tax credit for purchasing health coverage for children under a new section of the Internal Revenue Code. The curr_chunk introduces a tax credit for individuals equal to 80% of qualified health premiums paid in the taxable year. The credit is applied against tax liability at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability, with tax liability defined as the excess of total tax imposed and social security taxes over the credit allowed under section 32. The tax credit for individuals is equal to 80% of qualified health premiums paid in the taxable year. It is applied against tax liability at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability, with tax liability defined as the excess of total tax imposed and social security taxes over the credit allowed under section 32. Social security taxes include taxes imposed on income received by the taxpayer, self-employment income, and certain other amounts. The tax credit for individuals is equal to 80% of qualified health premiums paid in the taxable year. It is applied against tax liability at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability. The credit does not include social security taxes, self-employment income taxes, or taxes on amounts received by the taxpayer. The term 'social security taxes' excludes taxes eligible for a special refund under section 6413(c). Amounts paid under agreements with foreign affiliates equivalent to the taxes in subparagraph (A)(i) are treated as such taxes. The tax credit for individuals is equal to 80% of qualified health premiums paid in the taxable year, applied against tax liability at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability. Agreements with foreign affiliates equivalent to certain taxes are treated as such taxes. Definitions for terms like 'qualified health premium', 'health coverage', and 'qualifying young dependent' are provided. The amendments in this section relate to the purchase of health coverage for children and overpayments of tax, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1997.
